title: California rock lizard
text:
The California rock lizards are a <a href="genus">genus</a> (Petrosaurus) of <a href="New%20World">New World</a> <a href="lizards">lizards</a> in the family <a href="Phrynosomatidae">Phrynosomatidae</a>.
Geographic range.
They are <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to southern <a href="California">California</a> and <a href="Baja%20California">Baja California</a>, <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a>.
Habitat.
This lizard species lives almost exclusively on rock outcrops, <a href="boulder">boulder</a> piles, and canyon walls, where it shelters under rocks. Their habitat consists of <a href="arid">arid</a> and semiarid <a href="foothills">foothills</a> and canyons along the western margin of the <a href="Colorado%20Desert">Colorado Desert</a>.
Reproduction.
The courtship begins shortly after emergence in early spring. The eggs are laid around June and July.
Predators.
The few predators that could pursue this lizard are <a href="Crotaphytus">collared lizards</a> and <a href="Aves">avian</a> predators, such as <a href="hawk">hawk</a>s, <a href="raven">raven</a>s, and <a href="roadrunner">roadrunner</a>s.
Species.
The genus "Petrosaurus" contains three species.
